about.summary: There are some things that I wish were easier with the 'stringr'  or 'stringi' packages. The foremost of these is the extraction of numbers  from strings. 'stringr' and 'stringi' make you figure out the regular  expression for yourself; 'strex' takes care of this for you. There are many  other handy functionalities in 'strex'. Contributions to this package are  encouraged: it is intended as a miscellany of string manipulation functions  that cannot be found in 'stringi' or 'stringr'.

name: r-strex
raw_recipe:
{% set version = '1.1.1' %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}
{% set native = 'm2w64-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-strex
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/strex_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/strex/strex_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: a7905d0fe1e724b9db66be4fa5a11bddea81994d4b4b1d6e8de44fd663648e30

build:
  merge_build_host: True  # [win]
  number: 1
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}              # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_c') }}        # [win]
    - {{ compiler('cxx') }}            # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_cxx') }}      # [win]
    - {{posix}}filesystem        # [win]
    - {{posix}}sed               # [win]
    - {{posix}}grep              # [win]
    - {{posix}}autoconf
    - {{posix}}automake          # [not win]
    - {{posix}}automake-wrapper  # [win]
    - {{posix}}pkg-config
    - {{posix}}make
    - {{posix}}coreutils         # [win]
    - {{posix}}zip               # [win]
  host:
    - r-base
    - r-rcpp >=1.0.1
    - r-checkmate >=1.9.3
    - r-glue >=1.3.0
    - r-magrittr >=1.5
    - r-matrixstats >=0.50.0
    - r-ore >=1.4.0
    - r-processx >=3.3.1
    - r-rlang >=0.3.3
    - r-stringi >=1.3.1
    - r-stringr >=1.2.0
    - r-tibble >=2.0.1
  run:
    - r-base
    - {{native}}gcc-libs         # [win]
    - r-rcpp >=1.0.1
    - r-checkmate >=1.9.3
    - r-glue >=1.3.0
    - r-magrittr >=1.5
    - r-matrixstats >=0.50.0
    - r-ore >=1.4.0
    - r-processx >=3.3.1
    - r-rlang >=0.3.3
    - r-stringi >=1.3.1
    - r-stringr >=1.2.0
    - r-tibble >=2.0.1

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('strex')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('strex')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://rorynolan.github.io/strex, https://github.com/rorynolan/strex
  license: GPL-3
  summary: 'There are some things that I wish were easier with the ''stringr''  or ''stringi''
    packages. The foremost of these is the extraction of numbers  from strings. ''stringr''
    and ''stringi'' make you figure out the regular  expression for yourself; ''strex''
    takes care of this for you. There are many  other handy functionalities in ''strex''.
    Contributions to this package are  encouraged: it is intended as a miscellany of
    string manipulation functions  that cannot be found in ''stringi'' or ''stringr''.'
  license_family: GPL3
  license_file: '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/GPL-3'

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r

# Package: strex
# Title: Extra String Manipulation Functions
# Version: 1.1.1
# Authors@R: person("Rory", "Nolan", email = "rorynoolan@gmail.com",  role = c("aut", "cre"),  comment = c(ORCID = "0000-0002-5239-4043"))
# Description: There are some things that I wish were easier with the 'stringr'  or 'stringi' packages. The foremost of these is the extraction of numbers  from strings. 'stringr' and 'stringi' make you figure out the regular  expression for yourself; 'strex' takes care of this for you. There are many  other handy functionalities in 'strex'. Contributions to this package are  encouraged: it is intended as a miscellany of string manipulation functions  that cannot be found in 'stringi' or 'stringr'.
# Depends: R (>= 3.1), stringr (>= 1.2.0)
# License: GPL-3
# Encoding: UTF-8
# LazyData: true
# LinkingTo: Rcpp (>= 1.0.1)

# RoxygenNote: 6.1.1
# Suggests: testthat (>= 2.1.0), knitr, rmarkdown, pacman, covr, spelling, purrr
# SystemRequirements: C++11

# NeedsCompilation: yes

# Repository: CRAN
# Date/Publication: 2019-06-23 06:10:03 UTC

about.summary: There are some things that I wish were easier with the 'stringr'  or 'stringi' packages. The foremost of these is the extraction of numbers  from strings. 'stringr' and 'stringi' make you figure out the regular  expression for yourself; 'strex' takes care of this for you. There are many  other handy functionalities in 'strex'. Contributions to this package are  encouraged: it is intended as a miscellany of string manipulation functions  that cannot be found in 'stringi' or 'stringr'.
